children.text: It was a rough rise. Nobody in a rural performance would do the same. We had to perform in a fish market. He said ... It's funny now, but I almost punched him in his face. I was deciding whether we was going to jump him or not, right? He was like, well, You are street dancers, right? I was so mad because I was like, yeah, I guess we are. I was so mad. We performed in the middle of, like the race track. Shit, people knows, I can't come over. I'm like, we're entertaining people. That's what ... And you know what I did, though, I did the most point, the strongest hip hop performance art piece I could do. It started off, everybody, oh, yeah. All of a sudden it breaks out in a fight and we shoot each other. Pow, pow, pow, pow. And everybody goes. What the hell? You know? It was like, I was I actually loved that to set them up. Oh, I'm going to get them. They think we're going to be dancing and we're going to be doing the dance now. Duh, duh, duh, duh. Duh, duh, duh, duh. And all of a sudden that shit turned deep. Oh, I just was molested, some crazy shit. Like one of the pieces and I was like good for you. That's what you get for stereo-typing me.

I'm not on parole[inaudible 00:01:21] but it's different. If I wanted to do that, I would do my shows to be sensational instead be a spectacle, specifically for Broadway. I'm not the babysitter. Don't bring your kids. It's rated "R". And we used to say to them, if you bring your kids, have a conversation with your child afterwards. That's what we would bring at the pre-teen, eleven, twelve. And Q and A through the whole night.

And people for a long time, weren't really looking to accept that. You know it was just, Too, people are afraid of you, it was just so embarrassing. People would tell me that the work was embarrassing, it made them feel uncomfortable. I was like, good. You should, for coming in and thinking you was going to see somebody flip over somebody and do some shit.

People used to hire us, hey we want you to flip over the turntables and then we want. I had a person tell me, yeah, can you get people flipping? I said you want to give me flipping over the turntable money? Pfft. I hoe. I'll be a prostitute. See, that's what we're saying. When it's time to prostitute I want to get paid.

Don't call me and try to ask me to re ... Left Fox was another one. He was doing Carmen hip hop thing. They wanted me to read something, the script. So they gave me the script. And they're like, what do you think? Because at that time I was doing a lot of hip hop and Shakespeare kind of stuff. And so, I was like, I knew what the problem was. I read the script and they said, what do you think? I said, well, how much you going to give me? Give me fifteen G's and we good and I'll tell you my thoughts on it. You have something here and I know how to do it. Oh, hmm, we're going to have to call you back. Oh sure, call me. You do that. It's not going to happen.

We're not going to take my idea. I knew what the problem was. The problem was they weren't willing to be risky. They wanted to PC about it. What we did, when we were doing Shakespeare, we were risky about it. It was like, what the fuck? What's up bro? You know, thou art the villain, nigga, what? Like people didn't want to be real in the slang of it, the language of it, you know what I mean? And then we still would honor the language as well. You know what I mean? Shall I compare thee to a Summer's day? Thou are more lovely and more temperate. Rough winds doth shape the dulling buds of May and Summers' leafs have oft to a shorter date. Walk with me baby. You know what I mean?

We were going there and we came back with it. You know what I mean? But it was in when you thought about it. Because everybody was upset. Shakespeare, what? You have to ... Iambic pentameter and he changed the so ... I'm like, oh yeah, Shakespeare wrote all his shit in a bar that he owned, full of pimps, hoes and hookers that was there. I don't want to hear that. And he made half that shit up. Ya'll wasn't talking ... They weren't talking like that. He innovated and changed language. What other culture do you know that had did that? I'm sorry, hip hop? And what other culture speaks, that's in pop culture now, that's changed language and speaking rhyme and iambic pentameter? I'm sorry, hip hop? So, I don't know. All the historians was like. They hated it. And all the regular people who thought they knew about Shakespeare? Was ... eeecc. Which was really interesting.

So, sort of like fighting through that image also with hip hop and dance theater and me having that for my work, where I get to a point where ... You know I went to ... I forgot, it was a reception it was for Mark Morris. They were going on about Mark Morris, the whole thing, the whole thing, right?

So, a lady walked up to me and was like, you don't have to pretend you know who Mark Morris is. It's okay. Like that. I said actually, I do know who Mark Morris is and I ranned it down, blah, blah, blah, blah. I said, oh and you want to talk about Isadore Duncan? [inaudible 00:05:12] Maria Tagnioriole, whether it's court dancing, fire breathing, whatever, I'm good with that too. You want to know why I know that? Because I took time out to go to the library to get the book and read up on these people and why these people were important ... Why these choreographers were important and what they did and what they contributed to it. So, she just looked at me, and I said, have a good day.

But you know, you don't know who [inaudible 00:05:45] or any of that. But I have to do that. I have to know who these people are in order to navigate myself through this particular culture. That makes sense. Here's the ironic part of it. If the turntables was turned and it was black folk as the majority. It would be the same thing, I would just be a white dude having this interview with you. That's the ironic part. That's the crazy part. You know what I mean? Like, oh yeah, black people blah, blah, blah. You know what I mean?

So, it's kind of like, then like it's all relative. But then do you stop fighting? Do you stop moving forward? No. You just keep doing what you do and affecting the people you are supposed to affect on your journey. That's it. That's why I think what the company ... What I realized was I was supposed to do that. Because before that I kept trying to quit it. I fired the company twice, the whole company. I just walked in and said, okay, I'm done. I'm quitting. Boom.

And then the running joke, became who's this? You're fired? What you doing next week? That's like Randy. Because I said, yeah, we have a contract. I'm like shit, we've got to do this gig and then everything is nice on the gig and then everyone is like, oh yeah, I guess we can keep on going. Like that. But I always tried to quit. I had 3 ... 2 other things ... Three situations that changed my mind about quitting completely.

And that was a woman said she lost her kids. She saw me, saw us perform, saw my solo and said, I went back and got my kids. And I just ran into her randomly on the street. She asked me for a hug and I'm like, oh, okay. What's up? You know? And she said, I want to thank you because I got my kids back. I said, what do you mean? She said, well, when I saw you perform and I heard you guys speak and what have you, it inspired me and at the time, someone had took me to the show, I was on crack and I lost my kids to the state and once I saw the show, I decided I was going to get off crack and get my kids and now I have my kids. And I was like oh shit.

So, another time, another cat told me, hey, I saw your show. I was about to ... I was going to kill myself that night and someone ... And saw the solo and came and said, I decided that I want to live. I was like, okay. You know, that kind of shit.

And then I had another person, who was Ralph Lemon. I said, my girlfriend at the time, I was like, yeah, fuck it. I'm done. I'm quitting. Because she said, what's wrong with you? You've been moping. I said, I think I'm really done. It was like 1999. I'm like, I'm done. This is ... I'm tired. I just can't keep doing this. This is crazy. I'm fighting. I'm fighting people. It's not right. And I thought this was the right way. They're no different than the people in the commercial world. You know what I mean? They just have a language. You know what I mean?

So, we went to see Ralph Lemon. He gets off ... He finishes, he comes out and walks up to me and the first thing he says out of his mouth, he doesn't know nothing from anything. I hadn't seen him in years or whatever. He says, Rennie, don't quit. I looked at him. My girl looked at him. I was like ... He was like, we need you. Don't quit. And I was like, Oh, shit. And all of this stuff was like God talking to me. You know? This is my testimony. This is like God talking to me. It changed my life and made me keep doing what I'm doing.

I retied from teaching seven years ago. And then somehow ... and then, I realized shit, I need the next level is academia. How do I begin to shift to changing the thinking processes within academia. That's the new challenge in that way.

So, at the end of the day, Philadelphia informs all of that because one of the biggest riots happened there. North Philly is a home of boxers or fighters, we like to ... You know what I mean? Like, we like to get some shit done and get the hustle. We walk around back and forth at night not even doing anything thinking we doing some shit. Know what I mean? Like, that's how bad it is, like a Philly to me? You know what I mean?

And so, all of that, all of that informs my ... The work. My personal life informs my work a lot. It informs how I dance, how I see the dance. And I'm not afraid. I stopped having fear. I'm not afraid of dying. I'm not afraid of nobody. I'm not afraid ... I just ... No more fears. No fear. And when you ... I Feel like when you don't have any ... When you don't have fear, that's when you're progressive. You know what I mean?

And I learned early when I ask ... Chuck Davis, he was going to hire us to do Bam, Franklin County Music and he says, how much you ... He was on the phone, how much do you guys charge? I was like, Thirty-five. At that time, we got like a thousand dollars or five hundred or some shit like that. I was like, thirty-five. I didn't even say thirty-five hundred. I just said, thirty-five. I don't know what made me say it. So, he said, okay, well, let me get back to you. I hung up and I called the lead dance and I said, yo, I think I said too much. Oh my God. I don't get it. And he was like, okay, let's call him back and tell him, like ... Because I realized we were performing for three nights and that meant thirty-five hundred dollars each night, which meant that was ten thousand dollars. I was like, oh shit. That's too much money.

So, we were making a plan as to call him back and say maybe I made a mistake. You know, we go for like a thousand or something a night or something like that. Before I can get hang up, there was like a aaaannnn chzzz... those old rotary joints. I can't even get the ... the phone ring. Brrrgg... He's like, okay, no problem. I was like, oh shit. Yeah, we were in the money. Ten thousand. What? We were like there. We were dancing ... You know.

So, that was ... And I realized, like stopped having ... Stop being afraid, you know what I mean? And I put it out in the world. I said, you know what? I want to be the first hip hop dance company to earn a million dollars and the next year, we were 1.5. Not by two thousand. At our peak we were killing it ... Between 1999 to by 2004, like the highest paid dance company next to the ballet, national dance of so and so. As far as those ... and the major casts, like Mark Morris, Mark Dendy.
